Article.ArticleTitle: Conformational flexibility in the enterovirus RNA replication platform.

Abstract.AbstractText: A presumed RNA cloverleaf (5'CL), located at the 5'-most end of the noncoding region of the enterovirus genome, is the primary established site for initiation of genomic replication. Stem-loop B (SLB) and stem-loop D (SLD), the two largest stem-loops within the 5'CL, serve as recognition sites for protein interactions that are essential for replication. Here we present the solution structure of rhinovirus serotype 14 5'CL using a combination of nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy and small-angle X-ray scattering. In the absence of magnesium, the structure adopts an open, somewhat extended conformation. In the presence of magnesium, the structure compacts, bringing SLB and SLD into close contact, a geometry that creates an extensive accessible major groove surface, and permits interaction between the proteins that target each stem-loop.
